name.text: 29.1.2.10 scalar integral and closed path exercise

questiontext.text:
Consider the vector field \(\displaystyle \underline{F}={@aa@}x\underline{i}+(xz-{@bb@})\underline{j}+{@cc@}xy\underline{k}\) and two curves between \((0, 0, 0)\) and \((1, -1, 2)\) defined by \[\begin{eqnarray*} C_1&:&x=t^2,\qquad y=-t,\qquad z=2t\qquad (0\leq t\leq 1).\\ C_2&:&x=t-1,\qquad y=1-t,\qquad z=2t-2\qquad (1\leq t\leq 2). \end{eqnarray*} \]

  1. Find \(\displaystyle \int_{C_1}\underline{F}\cdot\underline{dr}\), \(\displaystyle \int_{C_2} \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr} \)

    \(\displaystyle\int_{C_1}{\underline G}\cdot \underline{dr} =\)[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

    \(\displaystyle\int_{C_2}{\underline G}\cdot \underline{dr} =\)[[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]][[feedback:prt1]]

  2. Find \(\displaystyle\oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr}\) where \(C\) is the closed path from \((0, 0, 0)\) to \((1, -1, 2)\) along \(C_1\) and back to \((0, 0, 0)\) along \(C_2\).

    \(\displaystyle\oint_C \underline{G} \cdot \underline{dr} =\)[[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]][[feedback:prt2]]

generalfeedback.text:
1. The path \(C_1\) is given in terms of the parameter \(t\) by \(x=t^2\), \(y=-t\) and \(z=2t\). Hence \[\begin{aligned} \underline{r} &= t^2\underline{i}-t\underline{j}+2t\underline{k}\\ \frac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}t} &= 2t\underline{i}-\underline{j} + 2\underline{k}\\ \underline{F} &= {@aa@}t^2\underline{i} + (2t^3-{@bb@})\underline{j} - {@cc@}t^3\underline{k}\\ \underline{F} \cdot \frac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}t} &= {@2*aa@}t^3 + {@bb@} -2t^3 - {@2*cc@}t^3 \\ &= {@2*aa-2-2*cc@}t^3+{@bb@} \end{aligned}\]

    Therefore we can evaluate the scalar integral as follows: \[\begin{aligned} \int_{C_1}\underline{F}\cdot\underline{dr} &= \int^1_0 {@2*aa-2-2*cc@}t^3+{@bb@} \mathrm{d}t\\ &= \left[{@(aa-1-cc)/2@}t^4+{@bb@}t\right]^1_0 \\ &={@(aa-1-cc)/2+bb@} \end{aligned}\]

    The path \(C_2\) is given in terms of the parameter \(t\) by \(x=t-1\), \(y=1-t\) and \(z=2t-2\). Hence \[\begin{aligned} \underline{r} &= (t-1)\underline{i}+(1-t)\underline{j}+(2t-2)\underline{k}\\ \frac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}t} &= \underline{i}-\underline{j} + 2\underline{k}\\ \underline{F} &= {@aa@}(t-1)\underline{i} + ((t-1)(2t-2)-{@bb@})\underline{j} - {@cc@}(t-1)^2\underline{k}\\ &= {@aa@}(t-1)\underline{i} + (2t^2-4t+2-{@bb@})\underline{j} - {@cc@}(t-1)^2\underline{k}\\ \underline{F} \cdot \frac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}t} &= {@aa@}(t-1) + -(2t^2-4t+2-{@bb@})- {@2*cc@}(t-1)^2 \\ &= {@aa@}t - {@aa@} + -2t^2 + 4t - 2 + {@bb@} - {@2*cc@}t^2 + {@4*cc@}t - {@2*cc@} \\ &= {@-2-2*cc@}t^2+{@aa+4+4*cc@}t + ({@-aa-2+bb-2*cc@}) \end{aligned}\]

    Therefore we can evaluate the scalar integral as follows: \[\begin{aligned} \int_{C_2}\underline{F}\cdot\underline{dr} &= \int^2_1 {@-2-2*cc@}t^2+{@aa+4+4*cc@}t + ({@-aa-2+bb-2*cc@}) \mathrm{d}t\\ &= \left[{@(-2-2*cc)/3@}t^3+{@(aa+4+4*cc)/2@}t^2 + {@-aa-2+bb-2*cc@}t\right]^2_1 \\ &=\left({@(-2-2*cc)/3@}(2)^3+{@(aa+4+4*cc)/2@}(2)^2 + {@-aa-2+bb-2*cc@}(2)\right) - \left({@(-2-2*cc)/3@}(1)^3+{@(aa+4+4*cc)/2@}(1)^2 + {@-aa-2+bb-2*cc@}(1)\right) \\ &= {@((-2-2*cc)/3)*8 + (aa+4+4*cc)*2 + (-aa-2+bb-2*cc)*2 - ((-2-2*cc)/3+(aa+4+4*cc)/2 -aa-2+bb-2*cc)@} \end{aligned}\]

  2. For the closed path \(C\) \[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle\oint_C\underline{F}\cdot\underline{d r} &=\displaystyle\int_{C_1}\underline{F}\cdot\underline{d r}\displaystyle\int_{C_2}\underline{F}\cdot\underline{d r}\\ &={@(aa-1-cc)/2+bb@}-{@((-2-2*cc)/3)*8 + (aa+4+4*cc)*2 + (-aa-2+bb-2*cc)*2 - ((-2-2*cc)/3+(aa+4+4*cc)/2 -aa-2+bb-2*cc)@}\\ &={@ta1-ta2@} \end{aligned}\]
